solution_line_template: {days_per_week} days a week Laura drives {school_round_trip_miles} miles to school, so Laura drives {days_per_week} x {school_round_trip_miles} = <<{days_per_week}*{school_round_trip_miles}={miles_to_school_per_week}>>{miles_to_school_per_week} miles to school in one week.

The supermarket is {supermarket_additional_distance} miles farther away than the school. Therefore the supermarket is {school_one_way_distance} + {supermarket_additional_distance} = <<{school_one_way_distance}+{supermarket_additional_distance}={supermarket_one_way_miles}>>{supermarket_one_way_miles} miles away from Laura's house

Laura drives {supermarket_one_way_miles} miles each way to and from the supermarket. Each trip is {supermarket_one_way_miles} x {round_trip_multiplier} = <<{supermarket_one_way_miles}*{round_trip_multiplier}={supermarket_round_trip_miles}>>{supermarket_round_trip_miles} miles.

Laura drives {supermarket_round_trip_miles} miles twice a week to visit the supermarket. Therefore she drives {supermarket_round_trip_miles} x {supermarket_trips_per_week} =<<{supermarket_round_trip_miles}*{supermarket_trips_per_week}={miles_to_supermarket_per_week}>>{miles_to_supermarket_per_week} miles in total a week to and from the supermarket.

In total Laura drives {miles_to_school_per_week} + {miles_to_supermarket_per_week} = <<{miles_to_school_per_week}+{miles_to_supermarket_per_week}={total_miles_per_week}>>{total_miles_per_week} miles each week.
